titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the O'Keeffe at Abiquiu.
titlestmt.author: by Matthew D. Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:55

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Photographs created by Myron Wood that document the homes and activities of artist Georgia O'Keeffe in Abiquiu, New Mexico, 1978-1981. Images include interiors and exteriors of the O'Keeffe residence in the village of Abiquiu and her summer home at Ghost Ranch and objects within them. The collection includes portraits of O'Keeffe, her acquaintances, including her gardener Estiben Suazo and his daughter and her maid, Candalaria Suazo, as well as her manager Juan Hamilton.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Patten, Christine Taylor, 1940- ( O'Keeffe at Abiquiu)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Sharon Keim on the Martin Greenblatt Foundation Book Fund in American Literature, 2007.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The O'Keeffe at Abiquiu Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Myron Wood, O'Keeffe at Abiquiu. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Most of the photographs in this collection appeared in Myron Wood and Christine Taylor Patten, O'Keeffe at Abiquiu (New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1995).

bioghist.head: Myron Wood (1921-1999)
bioghist.p: Myron Wood was a photographer and Assistant Curator of Photography at The Taylor Museum of the Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center from 1951 to 1961and the photographer for Colorado College for over thirty-five years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs created by Myron Wood that document the homes and activities of artist Georgia O'Keeffe in Abiquiu, New Mexico, 1978-1981. Images include interiors and exteriors of the O'Keeffe residence in the village of Abiquiu and her summer home at Ghost Ranch and objects within them. The collection includes portraits of O'Keeffe, her acquaintances, including her gardener Estiben Suazo and his daughter and her maid, Candalaria Suazo, as well as her manager Juan Hamilton.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs in the collection are arranged in the order the images appear in Myron Wood and Christine Taylor Patten, O'Keeffe at Abiquiu (New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1995), this consists of images in the book and an image from the back of the dust jacket, followed by images that did not appear in the work, which are arranged alphabetically by their title.

controlaccess.persname: O'Keeffe, Georgia, 1887-1986 -- Homes and haunts -- New Mexico -- Abiquiu
Patten, Christine Taylor, 1940- ( O'Keeffe at Abiquiu)

did.physdesc: 54 photographic prints on 35.6 x 43.2 cm mounts

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The location for all of the images (except where noted) depict the residence of Georgia O'Keeffe in Abiquiu, New Mexico.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Stone. The rock seemed to me like an animal skull, suggesting that things are not as they seem. (page 6)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: In the Studio. O'Keeffe's intense gaze was penetrating. (page 8)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Stoa. A stoa is a Greek architectural term for columns in front of an opening. (page 9)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Napping in the Afternoon Sun. Often Miss O'Keeffe's dogs, Inca and Jingo, would join her in a siesta. (page 11)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Gardener Estiben Suazo. Estiben (called Steven by Miss O'Keeffe) looked after the garden and did many household chores. When I showed her this photograph she said, "That sweet old thing." (page 16)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Miss O'Keeffe and Juan Hamilton. With its two skylights, the living room had perfect light. Juan suggested the picture, put two chairs together, and as he and Miss O'Keeffe sat their body gestures mirrored one another. (page 17)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Magic Snowfall. Miss O'Keeffe said the reason she bought the house was the black door. (page 18)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Ladder after Light Snow. In the manner of traditional New Mexican pueblos, a simple ladder leans against an outside wall. (page 29)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Inca. An old Japanese saying asserts that "Snow is a grandmother to the dog." (page 30)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Transformation. Soft, large flakes of a typical early spring snowfall sifted gently down. (page 32)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: After a Light Snow. The window in the background looks to me like a painting. (page 33)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: March Snow. Miss O'Keeffe told me with a chuckle that she was always afraid that the horns above the doorway would one day fall on her. (page 35)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: North Courtyard. Miss O'Keeffe walked regularly in the New Mexican sunlight. (page 36)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Bench Corner. A droll example of disrespect for architectural tradition. (page 38)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: The Gate. Rays of sun seemed to burn a pattern in this doorway. (page 39)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: North Garden Wall. Abstraction is seen through the wall to the garden. (page 40)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Shadow. Handwrought architecture leaves much for the eye to discover. (page 41)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Location: Ghost Ranch, Abiquiu, New Mexico

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Recuerdos (Memories). Cracks in the adobe wall mirror the patterns of the bones. (page 42)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Location: Ghost Ranch, Abiquiu, New Mexico

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Backbone. The wooden shelf that the bones rested on at Ghost Ranch ran like a backbone through the photograph. (page 44-45)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Elk Horns in a Passageway. These horns hung in the zaguan, a passage between the main entrance and the patio. Miss O'Keeffe told me that Estiben, for want of anything to do, once carved his initials on the back of the horns, much to her dismay. (page 47)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Fractured Sunlight. The door leads from the Indian room into the roofless room. (page 48)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: The Indian Room. When I made this photograph the calendar was rustling in the breeze; I took a clothespin from the basket to keep it still. It was the only object I moved or added in all the photographs I made at Miss O'Keeffe's house. (page 55)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: In the Roofless Room. Shadows from overhead gave the black pot an elegant setting. (page 57)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Pansies and Forget-Me-Nots, 1927. A wall with a banco (bench) in the living room. (page 65)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Mobile by Alexander Calder. Estiben's arrangement of firewood ready for lighting has its own beauty. (page 69)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Rattlesnake Skeleton. This skeleton was displayed in a glass-covered inset in the adobe back of the living room. (page 70)

did.unittitle: M's Fan a gift from Miss O'Keeffe

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Feather Fan. The fan reminded me of the range of tones in O'Keeffe's paintings. (page 71)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Wall Cove with Treasures. I printed this negative so that the shape of the niche barely appears in the stark white wall. (page 73)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Living Room Wall Fireplace. Another instance of Estiben's handiwork. (page 74)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Corner Fireplace in the Dining Room. The massive hearthstone is crowned by Estiben's beautifully laid fire. (page 75)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Daffodils and the Corner Fireplace. I was struck by the contrast of the delicate flowers against the rough plywood tabletop. (page 75)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Rock as Prototype. The earth shape of this rock echoes a form that O'Keeffe painted time and again. Some rocks in the garden were moved from season to season. This one never moved. (page 76)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Winter Garden. I photographed these massive stump forms in the snow to find the strongest relationship with the lacy background. (page 88-89)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Iris. Irises grew profusely in the garden. (page 90)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: D. H. Lawrence's Horse. Miss O'Keeffe laughingly referred to this skull, which she found on the Taos ranch where the novelist lived, as "D. H. Lawrence's horse." (page 91)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Wellhead Cover. Miss O'Keeffe and Estiben played a kind of chess with these stones. As they passed by, one person would make a move and the other would respond later, or the next day. (page 92-93)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Mulch Pile. I looked at these stalks for a long time, finding order in the designs and earthen tones. (page 94-95)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Fantastic Landscape. Water from snow melting on the roof and seeping up from the garden floor creates an otherworldly impression of mountains and village buildings. (page 97)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Among the Sheets. Estiben's daughter, Candalaria, was Miss O'Keeffe's housekeeper. (page 99)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Location: Ghost Ranch, Abiquiu, New Mexico

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: O'Keeffe House at Ghost Ranch. This is the house that the painter first occupied when she moved to New Mexico; the setting inspired many paintings. Miss O'Keeffe often climbed to the roof of this house to paint the glorious cliffs. (page 111)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Chimneys. The surface of the rough adobe and the adze marks on the lintel attest to the handwork of local architecture. (page 117)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: The Gorge. The Rio Grande River as it flows near Taos, New Mexico. (page 118)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Book Caption: Stones on the wellhead cover were used like chess pieces by O'Keeffe and her gardener, Estiben; the moved them almost every day. (Back of Dust Jacket)

did.unittitle: Myron Wood and Christine Taylor Patten, O'Keeffe at Abiquiu (New York: Harry N. Abrams)
